For each document, report the number of failures by Section 508 standard/WCAG Success Criterion. Please also provide the document name, document type, and document description.  Select One. (*Required) - c) Agency has results to report (Enter number of  electronic documents (MAX of 10)) - Text

Q4: b) Agency’s CIO Office or equivalent
Q7: a) Agency never conducts user testing with people with disabilities on web content for Section 508 conformance
Q8: c) All or some WCAG 2.1 Level AA Criteria
Q13: f) N/A - agency does not use a manual and/or hybrid testing methodology
Q16: a) Assist acquisition officials,b) Assist developers in designing accessible ICT, c) Evaluate web content, software, and/or hardware for Section 508 conformance, d) Provide accessibility training, e) Provide alternative formats f) Create or review documents for Section 508 conformance
Q20: b) Lack of resources, d) Lack of general awareness,e) Lack of or inadequate training,f) Lack of or inadequate authoring, development, and/or testing tools,h) Lack of or inadequate knowledge by acquisition officials,i) Lack of or inadequate knowledge by web content managers
Q21A: b) More ICT accessibility subject matter experts,c) More staff adequately trained to implement Section 508 requirements,e) Stronger Section 508 awareness across the agency,g) Increased implementation of established policies/procedures,h) Agency-wide access to tools necessary to create accessible digital content
Q22: e) The Section 508 program or equivalent has actively measured and well-defined performance metrics as well as authority in decision-making processes related to ICT
Q23: d) Agency's Section 508 Program Manager or equivalent has clearly defined roles and responsibilities with well-aligned performance measures and has sufficient authority and time allowed to effectively manage and coordinate agency's efforts to promote and ensure its ICT is accessible
Q24: e) Agency Section 508 Program or equivalent frequently provides support in response to ICT accessibility-related requests and questions
Q25: b) Agency sometimes includes Section 508 requirements in ICT governance, but inclusion is typically ad hoc
Q26: b) Resource needs are identified, but the resources provided or available are insufficient to support the Section 508 program's (or equivalent) needs
Q27A: e) Signed, published Section 508/ICT accessibility policy is appropriately referenced in other relevant agency policies and is regularly reviewed and updated
Q28: e) Agency includes consideration for ICT accessibility in its policy/directive creation, review, and management process, and most/all relevant policies include consideration for ICT accessibility requirements
Q29: c) Agency has a formally established complaint process with specific procedures for dealing with Section 508-related complaints (e.g., under the process for managing Section 504 complaints)
Q30: d) The agency maintains both public agency site(s) and intranet site(s) and instructions are provided on both OR the agency only maintains either public agency site(s) or intranet site(s) and instructions are provided there
Q31: e) In addition to response (d), agency has defined clear goals and objectives for ICT accessibility-related communications to promote awareness and education regarding Section 508 requirements, regularly measures communication outcomes, and incorporates feedback mechanisms to continually update and improve communications
Q32: e) Agency almost always follows formal processes to ensure communications are accessible, resulting in little to no accessibility issues for recipients, and agency employs feedback mechanisms to improve accessibility and usability of communication content
Q33: c) Agency has defined and regularly follows formal processes to ensure emergency communications are accessible
Q34: c) Agency has defined and regularly follows formal processes to ensure external emergency communications and associated resources are accessible
Q35: c) Agency provides or links to some guides, templates and tools for several types of electronic content on agency intranet/internet
Q36: d) Agency tracks non-conformant content and frequently creates and then takes action on a plan to remediate the content
Q37: e) Accessibility review is formally and fully integrated into the publication process, almost always includes accessibility reviews prior to electronic content publication, and includes feedback loops for continuous improvements/process refinement
Q38: d) Agency is currently updating ICT accessibility core values in the DEIA and/or mission-related strategic plan in the next strategic plan update (less than 1 year)
Q39: b) No, but agency has a timetable to begin implementation
Q40: a) Agency has not integrated ICT accessibility into professional development plans for responsible staff, and has no plans to do so
Q41: a) Agency Section 508 program or equivalent never engages with disability-related affinity groups
Q42: e) A risk model is almost always used to determine risk related to Section 508 non-conformance during the technology development lifecycle, including prioritization for remediating almost all ICT products, and resulting risk assessments are incorporated into milestone reviews and deployment decisions
Q43: e) Processes are almost always used for complaint escalation, when necessary, and actions are almost always taken to enforce accessibility and/or penalties (e.g., financial penalties are applied,  vendors/contractors removed from future consideration when ICT accessibility standards are not met or regular complaints are lodged and not addressed)
Q44: e) Knowledgeable agency staff is frequently integrated in lifecycle development activities
Q45: c) ICT accessibility requirements are regularly included in the technology development lifecycle
Q46: e) Web content testers almost always adhere to the required Section 508 conformance validation test process, have adequate training and tools reliably product consistent test results, and agency regularly evaluates and updates the Section 508 test process to adjust to evolving technology and Section 508 testing trends
Q47: b) Agency sometimes conducts comprehensive manual tests on web content for Section 508 conformance, but generally on an ad hoc basis
Q48: f) Unknown
Q49: e) Agency almost always tests electronic documents prior to posting
Q50: d) Agency frequently remediates Section 508 non-conformance issues based on risk evaluation, and includes accommodation plans
Q51: b) Some development/testing professionals have training in Section 508 web testing, but training is ad hoc
Q52: a) Solicitations do not or rarely include ICT accessibility requirements
Q53: a) Risk related to Section 508 non-conformance is not assessed during any part of acquisitions
Q54: a) Section 508 conformance is not included in market research for ICT products
Q55: b) Contract deliverables that are required to be Section 508 conformant are only sometimes verified prior to acceptance but generally on an ad hoc basis
Q56: e) The needs of individuals with disabilities are integrated into business needs processes, or equivalent, almost always included, and feedback loops are established for continuous refinement

Q105: ACUS is a micro agency with approximately 12 FTEs and it has no in-house IT professionals. ICT services and equipment, web hosting and development, etc. are all outsourced to vendors selected from the GSA Schedule. Payroll/HR services are provided by other federal agencies. ACUS uses widely available cloud-based services such Microsoft 365 and Zoom. No custom ICT is developed or procured. ACUS is currently working on a redesign of its website based on the US Web Design System that enables the agency to build an even more accessible, mobile-friendly website. The redesigned website will follow the requirements for manual 508 checks and will include an accessibility checker for content creators. The current website is still accessible because it has minimal images and uses plain English, high contrast, descriptive URLs, etc. Moreover, all documents that are published to the website are already in highly accessible pdf format. Finally, although ACUS does not have the resources to fully test documents in the manner outlined in this Assessment, the top 10 most accessed documents were identified and tested for accessibility to a large extent. All documents had similar results: excellent results on most requirements such as tagging content, logical reading order, lists, color contrast, no screen flicker, accessibility permission, no image-only PDF; failures tended to occur in tagging annotations (footnotes, generally), providing alternative text for figures (agency seal, generally), selection of primary language, title, and nesting.

Q105:
1)  We do not have the personnel or capabilities to do a per-page review of our internal and external websites, electronic documents, videos, and multi-functional devices that you have requested.  

2) Similar to DHS Continuous Diagnostic and Mitigation, and FedRAMP market place for cybersecurity program goals, ABMC would benefit from a shared service run by a designated agency to achieve Section 508 maturity.

3) Software licensing costs are also a major hurdles; small agencies normally do not receive licensing discounts when buying in small quantities.  GSA and OMB are in the best position to negotiate and influence licensing direction for small agencies for 508 compliance software.

Q105:
This agency (BVA) is a sub-component of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). BVA does not conduct 508 Compliance related activities. Section 508 Compliance is resident within VA's staff office, Office of Information and Technology (OIT), along with VA's CIO. VA/OIT is responsible for the Department's Section 508 program and policies. This agency (BVA) receives Section 508 Compliance support from OIT. Many questions within the survey did not have an appropriate answer for this agency (BVA) since it does not conduct these activities. The best of the available answers were selected; however, "N/A" would have been a more appropriate response most of the time but was not an available option. 
   
For the reporting period of this survey, the assessment tool utilized at that time was not configured to yield the information requested. Due to a contract protest, the AMP Tool was not available during the reporting period. The AMP tool is available across the Department for use as of July 2023, which is outside this reporting period.
   
Section 508 training courses are available on department-wide Talent Management System (TMS) for all VA employees and contractors.

Q105:
For testing tools, we have limited access to ANDI and to the Microsoft Edge Lighthouse accessibility tools.  The test results were challenging to map to the specific WCAG categories because they did not map 1:1. We included some limited results for our intranet home page but did not have resources to complete the testing for our pages.  We did identify our top 10 pages for the internet pages but did not have resources to conduct that testing either.  

Also, for the questions about interacting with persons with disabilities (6,7,41), we thought they were unclear. On the one hand, all of our 508 activities consider persons with disabilities because that's the entire point of 508. However, these questions seem to ask explicitly about whether we include persons of disability in our testing/assessments.  We do not explicitly do this so answered these questions as "none".

Q80B#1_7_2: MEMORANDUM FOR ALL DCMA EMPLOYEES - committed to the principles of Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO). EEO policies cover all personnel and employment programs, management practices and decisions to include recruitment, hiring, merit promotions, transfers, reassignments, training and career development, benefits, and separations. All federal civilian employees and applicants for employment shall be given fair treatment and equal employment opportunity regardless of their race, color, religion, age (40 and over), sex (including gender identity, sexual orientation and pregnancy), national origin, disability, reprisal, marital status, parental status, genetic information, political affiliation or other prohibited non-merit factors.

Q105: DISA maintains a Section 508 Program under the Office of the Chief Information Officer and acknowledges ICT Accessibility responsibilities and challenges across the organization including Joint Service Provider (JSP) and Joint Interoperability Test Command (JITC). Successes within the reporting period include implementation of mandatory Section 508 Accessibility Awareness training for all DISA employees, hyperfocus on accessibility during the development phase of a new public-facing DISA.mil site and required use of GSA’s Accessibility Requirements Tool (ART) for all acquisition packages in FY23 Q3.  The agency acknowledges challenges exist due to the lack of a comprehensive automated testing tool, inconsistent manual testing, and funding constraints.  Program strategy across the next reporting period will focus on ICT related objectives and prioritize identifying needed resources.

Q105: The Supply Chain Risk Management (SCRM) process remains a challenge for Section 508 procurement and use of assistive technology. DIA has additional security considerations in comparison to non-IC counterparts making it time-consuming to readily add assistive technology to the Agency 508 Baseline. The lack of standardization/reciprocity on assistive technology furthers inconsistencies across DoD agencies’ 508 program maturity levels. Additionally, the DHS Trusted Tester program takes approximately 90 days to complete and can only be accessed outside of DIA classified networks due to cyber security concerns. Also, the DHS Trusted Tester trainee must get 100% on all training modules and practice exam, making it almost impossible for team to ascertain certification.  Recommend offering an alternative free training program for 508 Compliance Tester(s) that is less time consuming, the mandated percentage is less than or equal to 90% and offers diverse options for automated testing tools.

Q105:
Staff attrition, coupled with organizational and functional realignments, has impacted DTRA’s legacy Section 508 (S508) coordination and synchronization capabilities. While many of the activities related to S508 compliance continued in isolation, the holistic, coordinated effort suffered. Agency leadership is committed to serving its stakeholders with disabilities and is re-building the central coordinating function of the S508 Program. This effort will guide efforts to improve understanding within DTRA’s administrative and operational mindset; integrate a wide range of Agency capability development and acquisition processes; establish responsive issue identification, management, and remediation processes; and test, assess, validate, and track compliance.
As part of this effort, DTRA is standing up a Coordination Board to guide efforts on providing individuals with disabilities access to and use of information and data comparable to individuals without disabilities. The DTRA S508 Program will work with disability-focused affinity groups and stakeholders, to better identify and address Information and Communications Technology (ICT) accessibility issues. This includes training to ensure stakeholders are aware of their responsibilities.
DTRA has allocated available resources for FY23 and FY24, budgeting also for dedicated staff and resources across the Future Years Defense Program, including tools and training for staff to detect and correct accessibility issues. In addition, the DTRA is reaching out to other DoD organizations to leverage their experience.
DTRA’s automated compliance assessment tool (Compliance Guardian) is being evaluated, along with other tools available commercially and through GSA, to aid in the development of our next “Annual Government-wide Section 508 Reporting 2024” Assessment Report. Utilizing current resources, DTRA is actively working to correct all issues discovered.

Q6_8_TEXT: In regards to acquisition, DHS created a tool titled ""DHS Accessibility Requirements Tool (DART)"", similar to GSA ART tool. All DHS acquisition personnel are required to use DART in all instances of soliciation development.   In regards to development, there are varioius practices across DHS with no consistency. Therefore, developers may consult with users with disabilities on an ad hoc/informal level.

Q20_13_TEXT: In the course of our 508 assessments at DHS, we've encountered a recurring issue with certain vendors overclaiming their accessibility of their products. Those vendors assert that their offerings fully comply with accessibility standards, however, our rigorous evlauations often reveal otherwise. When we attempt to provide feedback and present our findings, we are met with resistance rather than collaborative problem-solving. This creates significant barriers in our efforts to enhance overall accessibility, as the non-compliance of these products and the unwillingness of these vendors to rectify the issues hinder our mission to foster an inclusive digital environment.

Q105:
DHS HQ Section 508 program prioritizes addressing accessibility during the planning, design,  development, and implementation stages, rather than towards the end of the development life cycle.  

DHS HQ is focused on integrating accessibility into the agile development cycle. Additionally, DHS HQ is expanding on a human centric design approach, therefore they are applying not only Section 508 conformance but usability and accessibility best practices as well.

Q105: The current Section 508 contract was awarded in September of 2020 with the purpose of scaling up the program and establishing an outreach and training model for the Department.  The overall goal of this contract was to increase the general awareness of accessibility responsibilities. The next contract will be awarded in the fall of 2023, and will implement lessons learned from the current contract, including increased accessibility testing and expanding our footprint domestically and overseas by inserting 508 into existing processes with stricter enforcement. At the end of the reporting period for this assessment, the Department also hired its first FTE whose sole responsibility is Section 508. With the updated contract and the new hire, the State Department’s goal is to show progress in the Government-wide 508 assessment next year to our enterprise-wide approach to Section 508 with improvements surrounding acquisitions, metrics, and testing.

DAF Public Affairs Agency uses their own procured Pope Tech automated testing tool to test DAF public websites on AFPIMS; 65% of evaluated public webpages are conformant. DAF Public Affairs Agency does not have the manpower or expertise to do manual testing (including PDFs), so all scans are automated using Pope Tech. The 10 top viewed DAF public websites are: 
- acc.af.mil
- af.mil
- afgsc.af.mil
- afmc.af.mil
- afpc.af.mil
- airuniversity.af.edu
- amc.af.mil
- nationalmuseum.af.mil
- pacaf.af.mil
- spaceforce.mil

Q105:
The Department of Veterans Affairs' (VA) Section 508 Compliance is resident within VA's staff office, Office of Information and Technology (OIT), along with VA's Assistant Secretary/CIO. VA/OIT is responsible for the Department's Section 508 program, policy, and for providing support to the entire Department, including VHA, VBA, NCA, and BVA.    

The budget question does not delineate between budgeted versus executed dollars. For the survey time period, VA/OIT executed $2.6M of non-labor dollars in support of the 508 Accessibility program.
 
For the reporting period of this survey, the assessment tool utilized at that time was not configured to yield the information requested. Due to a contract protest, the AMP Tool was not available during the reporting period. The AMP tool is available across the Department for use as of July 2023, which is outside this reporting period.
   
Section 508 training courses are available on department-wide Talent Management System (TMS) for all VA employees and contractors.

Q105: Basically we do not have a 508 program.  We have a single person who technically is in charge of 508 for our agency, but has very little training, and there isn't a strong desire to add people or funds to help out.  Training at our agency is open and there are generally funds to take 508 training.  But since accessibility is not my primary job function, I also have to take training for primary job related skills.  So there is not much of a thought in our agency for 508 except to move our website to Drupal which our parent department takes care of.

Q80B#1_1_2: Document type: PDF,  Document Description: The Pilot’s Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge provides basic knowledge that is essential for pilots. This handbook introduces pilots to the broad spectrum of knowledge that will be needed as they progress in their pilot training. Except for the Code of Federal Regulations pertinent to civil aviation, most of the knowledge areas applicable to pilot certification are presented. This handbook is useful to beginning pilots, as well as those pursuing more advanced pilot certificates.
Q80B#1_2_2: Document type: PDF, Document Description: The Airplane Flying Handbook provides basic knowledge that is essential for pilots. This handbook introduces basic pilot skills and knowledge that are essential for piloting airplanes. It provides information on transition to other airplanes and the operation of various airplane systems. It is developed by the Flight Standards Service, Airman Testing Standards Branch, in cooperation with various aviation educators and industry. This handbook is developed to assist student pilots learning to fly airplanes. It is also beneficial to pilots who wish to improve their flying proficiency and aeronautical knowledge, those pilots preparing for additional certificates or ratings, and flight instructors engaged in the instruction of both student and certificated pilots. It introduces the future pilot to the realm of flight and provides information and guidance in the performance of procedures and maneuvers required for pilot certification.
Q80B#1_3_1: TITLE 14 OF THE CODE OF FEDERAL REGULATIONS (14 CFR) GUIDANCE MATERIAL
Q80B#1_3_2: Document type: PDF, Document Description: This advisory circular (AC) contains methods, techniques, and practices acceptable to the Administrator for the inspection and repair of nonpressurized areas of civil aircraft, only when there are no manufacturer repair or maintenance instructions. This data generally pertains to minor repairs. The repairs identified in this AC may only be used as a basis for FAA approval for major repairs. The repair data may also be used as approved data, and the AC chapter, page, and paragraph listed in block 8 of FAA form 337 when: a. the user has determined that it is appropriate to the product being repaired; b. it is directly applicable to the repair being made; and c. it is not contrary to manufacturer’s data.
Q80B#1_4_1: FAA AIRMAN KNOWLEDGE TESTING MATRIX Effective September 21, 2022
Q80B#1_4_2: Document type: PDF, Document Description: FAA AIRMAN KNOWLEDGE TESTING MATRIX Effective September 21, 2022
Q80B#1_5_2: Document type: PDF, Document Description: The Aviation Maintenance Technician Handbook–General (FAA-H-8083-30A) was developed as one of a series of three handbooks for persons preparing for mechanic certification with airframe or powerplant ratings, or both. It is intended that this handbook will provide basic information on principles, fundamentals, and technical procedures in the subject matter areas common to both the airframe and powerplant ratings. Emphasis in this volume is on theory and methods of application.

(Conformance Metrics) - 63. Applications - 64 and 50 web pages. All our web pages are built using 508 compliant templates and features. We do not custom code pages. The true number of issues was 0., 67 & 68. Apps - 64, Public web pgs -0., 70. Apps - 74. Internal intranet sites - built using 508 compliant templates/features. Do not use custom codes, and pgs assumed compliant, as the templates are compliant., 71. Apps - 1%, Internal Intranet web pgs - 95%., 72. Apps - 18, Internal Intranet pgs - unknown. Due to use of templates, non-compliance issues are primarily found in attached assets (ex. PDF, PowerPoint, etc.), 74. Apps - 74, Int Intrnet pgs - 50., 75. [The Federal Aviation Administration is committed to making our website(s) accessible to all users, including those with disabilities. Some content may not be in compliance, while some content may meet the required minimum standards. We are working to resolve these issues as we update existing websites and continue efforts to monitor and maintain acceptable compliance levels. If you encounter any accessibility barriers, please contact [name of Program Office POC] at [email address]. Thank you!]  (Acquisition and Procurement) 52. Required per AMS Guidance T.3.8.9. The FAA is in a developmental stage with the agency-wide S 508 Program, with training and development at the forefront.

Q105:
As the FDIC Program Manager, I look forward to reviewing our feedback and understanding how we can progressively implement best practices to develop a full 508 program. 
Not included- web platforms and if they are accessible. We are currently utilizing Adobe Experience Manager and we are moving to Drupal. We are unsure if this will affect accessibility or make accessibility better. 
Not included- testimony from assistive technology users and how to improve their needs. 
Not included- testimony from CIOs and their thoughts on improving their own 508 programs
Not included- where funding comes from- is it all from the CIOs shop, is it mixed? EEO and CIO, maybe HR shop? 

For lessons learned- not having the ability to go back to the questions has been frustrating, I would like to ability to copy and paste the format for top ten websites, documents, etc, to my team and then have easy access for input. 
Also- not being able to allow others to have access is also frustrating. 

Thank you for making the survey whole and meaning, this will allow for vast improvement for all agency 508 programs.

Q105: We conduct quarterly manual and automated testing of 31 external websites and maintain a 508 Compliance Dashboard that provides the 508 compliance status for system owners. We conduct monthly manual and quarterly testing of 6 main public-facing websites as well. We have tested 22 Internal SharePoint sites and regularly meet with Project Teams to address the remediation of identified defects. We integrate Section 508 language into every SOW, PWS, SOO that is produced and require ACRs/VPATs for all COTS products but do not have the resources to test applications at time of acquisition. We review all change requests and SELC gate reviews so 508 is integrated within the SELC lifecycle but there is more work to do to integrate within the acquisition life cycle. The FEMA redesigned mobile application is fully accessible which was a major accomplishment! We regularly test courses and are working towards testing our over 100 systems (42 to date). We have a signed Management Directive and are working on SOPs that compliment the signed MD. We evaluate documents as they are provided to us and are working to integrate within our TRIAD process. Thank you for this opportunity!

Q105:
Question 31: Agency regularly distributes formal communications from the Section 508 mailbox.
Question 37 and 49: Accessibility review is formally integrated into web publication process for content and documents created by the Web Team.  Publication of content and documents created by other agency staff is not reviewed prior to publication.  FERC is continuing to educate and train staff on how to create accessible content.
Question 43 and 44: FERC anticipates more Section 508 compliance guidance and requirements to be provided to contractors and to implement agency processes, in conjunction with the Acquisition and Procurement team, for staff to review, assess, and address non-compliant products or deliverables. FERC has acquired Section 508 training from Deque University and set mandatory training requirements for IT agency staff who are involved in technology development lifecycle activities.
Question 48: The response provided is applicable to automated accessibility testing for comprehensive, large-scale web content validation on the internet.  
Question 52: Majority of FERC solicitations are awarded from contract vehicles that include overarching Section 508 requirements e.g. GSA and NASA GWACs.
Question 53 and 57: The FERC Acquisition and Procurement team is working to identify and define the appropriate guidance and process for agency staff to ensure Section 508 conformance is reviewed and assessed as a regular part of the acquisition lifecycle.
Question 59 and 60: FERC offers optional and on demand Section 508 awareness training on ICT accessibility topics, how to use guides, templates, and tools to create accessible content. FERC has acquired training from Deque University and set mandatory training requirements for IT agency staff and contractors who are involved in technology development lifecycle activities.
Question 89: FERC has assessed the SharePoint based form used for telework agreements and put a plan in place to address the accessibility issues.

Our public content is on two servers. Content on the Drupal server is not checked at this time. 100% of content posted on the other server is conformant. All intranet content is checked using an automated checker starting recently.

Q102_14_TEXT: website: Menu items that have a dropdown menu include an "aria-haspopup" attribute that equals to "true".
Q102_15_TEXT: website: Menu items that have a dropdown menu include an "aria-expanded" attribute that equals to "false" that changes to "true" and back when opening or closing the dropdown.
Q102_16_TEXT: Website: Font icons, SVG or images that are being used as spacers, decorations or their purpose is already described by the content should include a "role" attribute that equals to "presentation" or "none".
Q102_17_TEXT: Website: Figure elements that are used to display images should have a "role" attribute that equals to "none" and the image provide itself should provide the description using an "alt" attribute.
Q102_18_TEXT: Website: Elements that behave as buttons but are built using other tags such as span, div, a or others, should include a "role" attribute that equals to "button".

Q105:
I am the new agency 508 program manager (one month) but not new to accessibility.  We parsed out several questions to other entities in our agency that provided responses and they are posted as received.  However, based on past accessibility experiences I cannot assume those responses provided to me are factually accurate and reflect the true accessibility conformance.

I plan to use this assessment and our responses as a roadmap to get my agency's 508 program back on track.  

In one area not reflected in the assessment, I found someone in our agency in the unknown past created a 508 "waiver" form to fast-track deployment of ICT, sans true documented full 508 conformance.  I stopped that and have received considerable backlash as a result.  I have the full support from the GSA accessibility team, the US Access Board, and my parent (USDA) 508 office to get my agency's 508 program back on track, especially after discovering this "wavier."

Lastly, the acquisition and in-house development accessibility processes defined on the section508.gov website are very difficult to follow.  The are convoluted and easy to make mistakes.  I am attempting to write a much simpler set of stove-piped instructions for agency staff to follow the required convoluted paths they must take.  Please fix this on the website for all of us.

Q105: As a microagency, we do not currently have dedicated staff, subject matter experts, or funding for 508 implementation. We have a desire to improve in this area in the future, and are currently conducting an equity assessment to better understand our accessability baseline. We will use the outcomes of the assessment to refine and prioritize our agency strategic goals including with respect to 508 compliance.

Q105:
NASA recently reorganized our enterprise IT services. Prior to this, management and oversight of the Section 508 program was delegated to the local level. As part of the reorganization, the function was centralized within OCIO with an Agency IT Accessibility Lead role was established to oversee the program full time. The program is in the process of being reformulated and updated.
NASA tracks websites at the site level, not the page level. If a page on a website is nonconformant, the site is considered nonconformant. NASA is releasing a new public website that will dramatically improve the experience of people with disabilities and be fully 508 compliant. This site will be released FY23 Q4, replacing the current https://www.nasa.gov/. 508 compliance was a content management system selection factor, and an independent accessibility vendor was hired to test and report issues for resolution to strive for full conformance at every step of the development lifecycle. 
NASA does not track intranet sites to the same level as public sites; hosting is distributed and responsibility is delegated to the local level. While we can estimate the number of sites, we are not able to establish the number of pages with any degree of accuracy as many of them are access-controlled. 
In our contracting and software development lifecycle, we don’t manage the risk of nonconformance; we address cost, schedule, and technical risk. We require that ICT be compliant with Section 508 in order to purchase it or to pass a key decision review. Rather than a risk, it’s considered a project constraint.  In the case of vendor provided tools and services, we rely on VPAT and ACR results for verification, we don’t conduct independent testing. 
NASA has a large contractor workforce. We expect that it is our vendors’ responsibility to provide staff with the expertise to perform the function we contracted them to do; therefore NASA does not typically provide training to contractors on Section 508.

Q105: Our program is strongest with acquisitions, requirements, reviewing VPATs and ACRs, and working with vendors to request changes and improvements in compliance. Earlier this year, I created a plan to strengthen the Section 508 program and capabilities at NARA. Shortly thereafter, I received the new set of questions for the OMB maturity report. The new questions tracked very closely to the plan I had created. In short: identify training needs and provide more training; create templates and guidance for document creation; identify needed tools and associated budget needs; create a plan to scan and remediate the backlog of documents, especially pdf, on both internal and external websites; introduce in-house testing using the DHS Trusted Tester model. For example, in Qs 78-80, we are not currently able to manually test the pages and documents; but the agency is making plans to remedy that. NARA has also just brought in a new DCIO who will be in charge of making changes to the 508 program and providing oversight for the new initiatives.

Q105:
This agency (NCA) is a sub-component of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). NCA does not conduct 508 Compliance related activities. Section 508 Compliance is resident within VA's staff office, Office of Information and Technology (OIT), along with VA's CIO. VA/OIT is responsible for the Department's Section 508 program and policy. This agency (NCA) receives Section 508 Compliance support from OIT. Many questions within the survey did not have an appropriate answer for this agency (NCA) since it does not conduct these activities. The best of the available answers were selected; however, "N/A" would have been a more appropriate response most of the time but was not an available option. 
   
For the reporting period of this survey, the assessment tool utilized at that time was not configured to yield the information requested. Due to a contract protest, the AMP Tool was not available during the reporting period. The AMP tool is available across the Department for use as of July 2023, which is outside this reporting period.
   
Section 508 training courses are available on department-wide Talent Management System (TMS) for all VA employees and contractors.

Q105: NCD's website is being finalized using Cloud.gov Pages incorporating the U.S. Web Design System standards. The current NCD.gov site will be taken offline and replaced with the new beta.ncd.gov site that will greatly improve 508 compliance as migration of content and remediation of data is complete. Due to the amount of content on our website spanning almost 40 years and limited resources available, the agency has made slow incremental progress identifying both legacy and current content requiring 508 remediation on a prioritized basis while operating two websites during the creation, migration and closeout of the old site.

Q105:
NOTES: 

A 508 Action Team was formed in 2022 to aid in the maturity of NIST's 508 program. The team created accessible templates for NIST research/scientific papers, trained authors on how to use the templates, and reviewed papers for compliance; raised awareness about 508/accessibility via ongoing campaigns; provided a variety of resources through a dedicated 508 website; and created a guide on how to create accessible PDFs. 

Also, the role of NIST 508 Compliance Manager is not my primary position; however, since taking over the role, I have responded to all 508-related inquiries in a timely mannner, reaching out to the U.S. Access Board, the Chairperson of the Federal CIO Council Accessibility Community of Practice Industry Outreach Program, the GSA 508 Listserv, and other resources, when needed, so that I can assist staff.

For Question #5:  I added .2 of my salary plus the cost of our 508 testing tools.

For Question #70: I entered “0” because a number was required; however, I actually have no way of determining the proper value. Our internal pages were designed with 508/accessibility criteria in mind, yet content authors occasionally fail to use appropriate headings, etc. We don't have a tool to automatically test intranet pages; pages must be tested manually, but I can’t verify how many have been tested.

For Questions #80A,81A,83,87,101: I do not have the resources available to report on these questions, but I will have that info available in a future report.

For Question #84, Microsoft’s ACR reports that it conforms to applicable 508 standards, but it document three areas where it only “partially supports.” These include WCAG criteria 1.4.3, 2.1.1, and 2.4.7.

For Question #85, NIST uses a number of virtual meeting tools (BlueJeans,Google Meets, Teams,WebEx, Zoom for Govt).  These platforms claim to be 508 compliant according to federal government rules, with few exceptions. 

For Q#104, I would like to note that some exceptions are documented in a VPAT.

Q105: NIH has recently appointed a dedicated Section 508 Program Manager, marking a significant step towards enhancing our commitment to accessibility. We are currently in the midst of revitalizing our program, with a strong focus on continuous improvement and adherence to Section 508 standards. While we are proud of the progress we've made so far, we acknowledge that there is always room for growth and enhancement. As such, we anticipate that future Assessments will reflect marked improvements in our program's effectiveness and reach.

Q79B#1_3_2: Under the National Labor Relations Act (NLRA or the Act), employees have the right to communicate with other employees at their workplace about their wages.  Wages are a vital term and condition of employment, and discussions of wages are often preliminary to organizing or other actions for mutual aid or protection.
Q79B#1_6_2: The National Labor Relations Act forbids employers from interfering with, restraining, or coercing employees in the exercise of rights relating to organizing, forming, joining or assisting a labor organization for collective bargaining purposes, or from working together to improve terms and conditions of employment, or refraining from any such activity. Similarly, labor organizations may not restrain or coerce employees in the exercise of these rights.
Q79B#1_7_2: Section 7 of the National Labor Relations Act states in part, “Employees shall have the right. . . to engage in other concerted activities for the purpose of collective bargaining or other mutual aid or protection.” Strikes are included among the concerted activities protected for employees by this section. Section 13 also concerns the right to strike.
Q79B#1_8_2: Employees have the right to unionize, to join together to advance their interests as employees, and to refrain from such activity. It is unlawful for an employer to interfere with, restrain, or coerce employees in the exercise of their rights. For example, employers may not respond to a union organizing drive by threatening, interrogating, or spying on pro-union employees, or by promising benefits if they forget about the union.

Q105: The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) was flat-funded at $274.2 million from FY 2014-FY 2022, resulting in a loss of more than 25% of our purchasing power, and a loss of nearly 400 FTEs in recent years. Due to this lack of resources, the NLRB has not had the resources and capacity to build a formal Section 508 Program. But even within these constraints, the Agency has been striving to ensure and expand accessibility in all aspects of its operations.  In particular, the NLRB’s OCIO staff have taken steps, where possible, to make NLRB processes accessible to all, including by providing an email link on our public website for any member of the public to request assistance.  In addition, this fiscal year (FY2023), NLRB leadership authorized contracting with a Section 508 Compliance Specialist to assist the Agency in assessing appropriate tools for evaluation, implementing Section 508 training for OCIO staff and others, and standing up a formal Section 508 Compliance Program.

Q105: It would be nice if the next report allowed the agency's designated primary POC to allow direct access to the survey portal for colleagues/stakeholders to directly contribute responses in draft for the primary POC to validate and submit to agency senior leadership for approval and authorization to submit similar to the survey portal used for FY2015.  Please reprogram the survey portal to include a back button that lets users go back to change a response without the need to fully complete a section.  Also, it would be great if you leveraged and incorporated work flow routing and approval processes to allow the agency primary POC to assign and route questions to team members to enter their responses directly into the survey portal as draft and hit save to send the primary POC a notification that they've finished and also included a workflow that allows the primary POC to route the fully completed survey responses to leadership for review and a button to click approval that notifies the primary POC he/she is authorized to submit the report to OMB/GSA as final.  We should also include a mini training video that provides a preview/demo of the survey portal tool similar to the really helpful live demo Kristen provided to some agencies upon request.   Also, please consider incorporating pop-up messaging that advises questions x, y and z were skipped based on your response to question r or some similar alert that, for instance, explains why the tool advanced from question 95 to question 98 and then from question 98 to question 101.  This was really confusing.

Q20_13_TEXT: The agency takes Section 508 compliance seriously.  However, due to funding constraints, we have traditionally focused our Section 508 efforts on agency investigative reports, safety recommendation reports, other external reports that include website content, and DEIA components.  Given this assessment, and with additional resources, we will be able address 508 requirements across the agency in a more comprehensive manner to include: Section 508 program creation and management; Internal and external communications; Information technology solutions; Training; Acquisitions; and Budgeting.
Q21A: a) Additional funding to aid Section 508 implementation,c) More staff adequately trained to implement Section 508 requirements,h) Agency-wide access to tools necessary to create accessible digital content,l) More accountability for Section 508 implementation across the technology development lifecycle,m) Other (please specify)
Q21A_13_TEXT: The agency takes Section 508 compliance seriously.  However, due to funding constraints, we have traditionally focused our Section 508 efforts on agency investigative reports, safety recommendation reports, other external reports that include website content, and DEIA components.  Given this assessment, and with additional resources, we will be able address 508 requirements across the agency in a more comprehensive manner to include: Section 508 program creation and management; Internal and external communications; Information technology solutions; Training; Acquisitions; and Budgeting.

Q105: The agency takes Section 508 compliance seriously.  However, due to funding constraints, we have traditionally focused our Section 508 efforts on agency investigative reports, safety recommendation reports, other external reports that include website content, and DEIA components.  Given this assessment, and with additional resources, we will be able address 508 requirements across the agency in a more comprehensive manner to include: Section 508 program creation and management; Internal and external communications; Information technology solutions; Training; Acquisitions; and Budgeting.

Q105:
OGE Section 508 Plan
OGE is a micro-agency with a micro-budget and staff. OGE does not have the human capital or budgetary resources to establish and support a standalone Section 508 Program.

Although OGE does not have a budget for additional FTEs, it does have a small budget for 508 tools (currently $7,000.00 annually) to support compliance activities.

Section 508 Policy 
By December 31, 2023, OGE will prepare a comprehensive, agency-wide Section 508 Policy. 

The Policy will require mandatory Section 508 training for the following employees:
General training for all employees
Contracting Officer's Representative (COR)
Purchase Card Holders
Developers
Web Content Managers

The Policy will seek to accomplish the following:
Assist acquisition personnel to assess Section 508 requirements in the acquisition process 
Assist developers in designing accessible ICT 
Evaluate web content, software, and/or hardware for Section 508 conformance
Provide accessibility training to the groups identified above
Provide alternative formats for Section 508-compliant documents
Assist in the creation or review of documents for Section 508 conformance

The Policy will seek to address OGE's primary challenges in implementing and complying with Section 508, including:

Lack of human capital and budgetary resources
Raising general awareness
Addressing training needs for 508 compliance
Increasing knowledge of web content managers
Increasing knowledge of developers

The Policy will seek to address OGE's primary challenges in implementing and complying with Section 508, including:
Lack of human capital and budgetary resources
Raising general awareness
Addressing training needs for 508 compliance
Increasing knowledge of web content managers
Increasing knowledge of developers

OGE will investigate the feasibility of acquiring and using automated accessibility testing tools.

Q105:
Agency comment on conformance testing: All new websites and webpages are tested with manual and automatic methods before approval to deploy. After deployment an average of 70% of sites and pages are subjected to an automated continuous crawl for compliance test each month. Any page found to be non-conformant at Levels A and AA are placed into the queue for remediation.
Agency comment on ICT remediation: All development SDLC mandate conformance in design/selection and pre-deployment validation.
Agency comment on 508 budget. 508 conformance is not a line item in the budget. Funding is an embedded consideration in all acquisition and development activities as per our SDLC.
Agency comment. Agency is a component of USDOJ and conforms to DOJ Accessibility Order 0902

Q105: (1) Program office: since July 2022, the program office has had two full-time employees with additional assistance from employees within their office. Before that, for about three years, it had one full-time employee. Before that, the program manager had other major duties. The program has grown significantly but unevenly with these changes. OPM now has a genuine appreciation for and dedication to accessibility, as evidenced by our documents program. The challenge is to expand into other areas. (2) Policy: Q27: our policy provides high-level roles and responsibilities. Future appendices will expand on those. (3) Acquisition and procurement: we have been using an outdated clause in contracts that references the previous standards. We recently successfully embedded Section 508 in a large IT project throughout the acquisition and IT lifecycles. We are conducting a pilot to replace the outdated clause and incorporate Section 508 throughout these lifecycles more broadly. (4) Content creation: our most advanced area is content accessibility. We focus on incorporating accessibility from the beginning and are working to create more new content in HTML rather than PDF. (5) Conformance metrics: Q79: we tested only seven pages because one of the top ten no longer exists and two couldn’t be tested because they appear only for a few seconds, at most, for example, when a user logs out of USAJobs. Q80: in testing the top ten documents, we identified errors in the system that generates pay table PDFs. The system has been updated and is in quality review presently. New PDFs for 2023 will appear on opm.gov this calendar year, and future pay tables will be generated by the remediated system. Q63-68 and 70-75 – Our test methodology focuses on testing software/application based on the functionality. Section 508 issues are tracked against an application (not web pages as requested) using the 38 Success Criteria where applicable.  For example, if an application has 50 pages, it is a single entity rather than 50 web pages. We went through all defects opened during this reporting period and tracked defects to a specific webpage where we could and included those in our response.

Q105: I am the 508 Program Managers and I started in January 2023, I have one 508 SME full time contractor and one 508 SME part time contractor on the 508 team for the entire agency.  Prior to myself there was 508 Program Manager (no other 508 staff) and there was no formal hand off and not a lot of documented in place.   Due to resource constraints, we are unable to manually test the organization comprehensively. We have adopted CommonLook as our chosen tool for addressing remediation needs in PDFs, and we have recently introduced JAWS, ANDI, and Zoom Text into our workflow.  For evaluating 508 compliance on websites, we implement automated testing approaches, which encompass the utilization of Axe Monitor. Currently, we are actively scanning approximately 13 public-facing websites, allowing us to gather data and respond to survey inquiries based on these scans. However, for our internal intranet sites, Axe Monitor scanning is not feasible due to limitations, and we lack the necessary resources to test all the intranet sites.

Q105:
DFC is a new agency. The 508 program is just getting stood up in FY23. Additionally the DEI Director was just hired in FY23 and the HR Director had turn over in FY23. Resourcing has been our biggest issue to getting the program stood up and we inherited many of the former OPICs technology which was not seemingly following much of any standards/orders so it has been a prioritization of clean up on the IT side of the house.

Would like to note (in a nice way :)) this survey is not 508 compliant and it did not have back buttons to allow us to go in between sections as we obtained answers

Q79B#1_2_2: The USGS monitors and reports on earthquakes, assesses earthquake impacts and hazards, and conducts targeted research on the causes and effects of earthquakes. We undertake these activities as part of the larger National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program (NEHRP), a four-agency partnership established by Congress.
Q79B#1_3_2: Find recent or historic earthquakes, lists, information on selected significant earthquakes, earthquake resources by state, or find webservices.
Q79B#1_4_2: The USGS Hawaiian Volcano Observatory issues Volcano Updates for K?lauea as activity warrants.
Q79B#1_4_3: K?lauea - Volcano Updates | U.S. Geological Survey (usgs.gov)
Q79B#1_5_2: There are about 170 potentially active volcanoes in the U.S. The mission of the USGS Volcano Hazards Program is to enhance public safety and minimize social and economic disruption from volcanic unrest and eruption. We deliver effective forecasts, warnings, and information about volcano hazards based on a scientific understanding of volcanic processes to accomplish our mission.
Q79B#1_5_3: Volcano Hazards Program | U.S. Geological Survey (usgs.gov)
Q79B#1_6_2: Originally written by Lisa Wald (U.S. Geological Survey) for “The Green Frog News”
Q79B#1_6_3: The Science of Earthquakes | U.S. Geological Survey (usgs.gov)
Q79B#1_7_1: What is an earthquake and what causes them to happen?
Q79B#1_7_2: An earthquake is caused by a sudden slip on a fault. The tectonic plates are always slowly moving, but they get stuck at their edges due to friction. When the stress on the edge overcomes the friction, there is an earthquake that releases energy in waves that travel through the earth's crust and cause the shaking that we feel.
Q79B#1_7_3: What is an earthquake and what causes them to happen? | U.S. Geological Survey (usgs.gov)
Q79B#1_8_2: Topographic maps became a signature product of the USGS because the public found them - then and now - to be a critical and versatile tool for viewing the nation's vast landscape.
Q79B#1_9_2: Views of K?lauea summit from live webcams.
Q79B#1_10_2: HVO monitors earthquakes and the active volcanoes in Hawaii, assesses their hazards, issues warnings, and advances scientific understanding to reduce the impacts of volcanic eruptions. Communicating the results of our work to the public, emergency managers, and the scientific community is an important aspect of the HVO mission.
Q79B#1_10_3: Hawaiian Volcano Observatory | U.S. Geological Survey (usgs.gov)

Q80B#1_6_2: This Memo to All Banders (MTAB 104) was released in May 2023. Subjects in this memo are 1. The Chief’s Chirp; 2. Alerts – Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza and reminder that banders cannot submit data through Bandit, only manage data; 3. Staff updates – Jennifer McKay joins the BBL; 4. News – Database migration is happening now!, Bird Banding Lab data and window collisions;  5. A note from the permitting shelves – last call for fall banding season permitting, social media recommendations, and permittees check your contact information; 6. A note from the supply room – 1C bands available; 7. Data management – Bander Portal video tutorials, Bander Portal Portal Office Hours, how to contact us, and status codes for banded birds taken from artificial nest structures; 8. Frequently asked questions – what’s the difference between encounters and recaptures?; 9. Auxiliary marker corner; 10. Banding and encounter highlights; 11. Message to the Flyways - including Canada and Cackling Geese code updates; 12. Moments in history; 13. Recent Publications; 14. Upcoming events; and 15. Request for information.
Q80B#1_7_1: The Water Cycle (Fill-in-the-blank, 8.5x11-inch PDF) | U.S. Geological Survey (usgs.gov)
Q80B#1_7_2: This 8.5x11-inch fill-in-the-blank worksheet, released in 2022, depicts the global water cycle. It shows how human water use affects where water is stored, how it moves, and how clean it is. This diagram is available in English and Spanish. For each language, the diagram is available as an image (PNG), as a 26x38-inch poster (PDF), as a 8.5x11-inch handout (PDF), and as a 8.5x11-inch fill-in-the-blank worksheet (PDF).  A comprehensive text description of the diagram is also available.

Q105:
This agency (VBA) is a sub-component of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). BVA does not conduct 508 Compliance related activities. Section 508 Compliance is resident within VA's staff office, Office of Information and Technology (OIT), along with VA's CIO. VA/OIT is responsible for the Department's Section 508 program and policy. This agency (VBA) receives Section 508 Compliance support from OIT. Many questions within the survey did not have an appropriate answer for this agency (VBA) since it does not conduct these activities. The best of the available answers were selected; however, "N/A" would have been a more appropriate response most of the time but was not an available option. 
   
For the reporting period of this survey, the assessment tool utilized at that time was not configured to yield the information requested. Due to a contract protest, the AMP Tool was not available during the reporting period. The AMP tool is available across the Department for use as of July 2023, which is outside this reporting period.
   
Section 508 training courses are available on department-wide Talent Management System (TMS) for all VA employees and contractors.

Q105:
This agency (VHA) is a sub-component of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). BVA does not conduct 508 Compliance related activities. Section 508 Compliance is resident within VA's staff office, Office of Information and Technology (OIT), along with VA's CIO. VA/OIT is responsible for the Department's Section 508 program and policy. This agency (VHA) receives Section 508 Compliance support from OIT. Many questions within the survey did not have an appropriate answer for this agency (VHA) since it does not conduct these activities. The best of the available answers were selected; however, "N/A" would have been a more appropriate response most of the time but was not an available option. 
   
For the reporting period of this survey, the assessment tool utilized at that time was not configured to yield the information requested. Due to a contract protest, the AMP Tool was not available during the reporting period. The AMP tool is available across the Department for use as of July 2023, which is outside this reporting period.
   
Section 508 training courses are available on department-wide Talent Management System (TMS) for all VA employees and contractors.

Q105: The Agency receives all of its IT support from a central Office of the CIO and all of its IT accessibility support from a central Section 508 Program Office, both of which support multiple agencies. As such, many of the topics being addressed by this assessment are not controlled by the Agency, nor are they visible to Agency staff.
